metadata./Title: Dysphasia: metastatic prostate cancer to the leptomeninges: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Leptomeningeal metastasis occurs in 5% of patients with prostate cancer and indicates a very poor 
prognosis.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 60-year-old Caucasian male patient diagnosed with metastatic castration-resistant prostate 
cancer with sclerotic bone metastases and soft tissue metastases underwent multiple courses of chemotherapy 
and hormone therapy. The diagnosis of prostate cancer is based on elevated prostate-specific antigen levels and tissue biopsy. He subsequently presented with expressive aphasia. Nonspecific, diffuse irregular dural/pachymeningeal 
thickening enhancement was noted on magnetic resonance imaging. Upon evaluation by neurology, electroencephalogram was negative for an epileptiform correlate. The workup included a lumbar puncture to rule out infectious 
etiology. The patient’s neurological status stabilized, and he was discharged home with a plan for continued therapy 
with abiraterone and prednisone. Due to advanced malignancy, the patient enrolled in hospice and died 3 weeks 
after hospital discharge.
Conclusions Central nervous system metastasis occurs very rarely in prostate cancer. With the increase in life expectancy and advances in oncologic therapy for prostate cancer, physicians should be aware of and consider central 
nervous system metastasis in men aged 50 years and above.
Keywords  Prostate cancer, CNS metastasis, Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer
Background
Prostate cancer is the second leading cause of death in 
the USA after heart disease. Metastasis often involves the 
axial skeleton (84%), pelvic lymph nodes (10.6%), liver 
(10.2%), and thorax (9.1%), with the remainder occur ring at multiple sites (18.4%) [1–3]. Bone metastasis of 
the skull is a known complication of metastatic prostate 
cancer; however, it is uncommon for patients to develop 
leptomeningeal involvement, which is mostly found in the dura mater [4]. A total of 1–6% of prostate cancer 
leptomeningeal metastasis are found in post mortem 
examinations [5]. Neurologic complications of metasta sis include localized back pain (90–95%), weakness (75–
80%), autonomic dysfunction (57%), and sensory changes 
(50%) when present in the spinal cord. Brain metastasis 
complications are limited to headaches (34%), motor def icits (26%), altered mental status (23%), and seizures (8%), 
and are at times asymptomatic [6]. The diagnosis of pros tate cancer is based on elevated prostate-specific antigen 
(PSA) levels and tissue biopsy. Metastatic prostate cancer 
presenting with aphasia is rare (3%) and not commonly 
seen [7]. We report a 60-year-old male patient who devel oped aphasia with nonspecific magnetic resonance imag ing (MRI) findings concerning for diffuse irregular dural/
pachymeningeal thickening and enhancement, suspicious 
for prostate cancer metastasis.Open Access

Case presentation
A 60-year-old Caucasian male was diagnosed with meta static castration-resistant prostate cancer with extensive 
sclerotic bone metastases and soft tissue metastases in 
the left mesorectum. The diagnosis of prostate cancer is 
based on elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels 
and tissue biopsy. Patient underwent multiple courses of 
hormone and chemotherapy including enzalutamide and 
rucaparib on clinical trial A031902 (started 09/19/22). 
The patient was on treatment when prior and then devel oped expressive aphasia. Past medical history includes 
right ear fluctuating hearing loss with atypical Meniere’s, 
status post-intratympanic steroid injection two times and 
chronic subdural hematoma. Family history is signifi cant for bipolar disorder type 1 in his brother and sister, 
Crohn’s disease in his brother, dementia in his mother; 
depression in his brother and mother, myocardial infarc tion in his father, hyperlipidemia in his father and mother, 
rheumatoid arthritis in his mother, and urolithiasis in his 
mother. Physical exam is significant for mild bradykine sia and rigidity but pronounced bilateral lower extremity 
weakness, which was mild and diffuse, and slightly more 
pronounced on the left. Patient reports double vision 
with lateral gaze and vertical gaze extremes, as well as 
decreased sensation on the chin and lower lip. He also 
has sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear. Computed 
tomography (CT) and MRI evaluations were unremarka ble for evidence of acute ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke 
and CT angiogram was unremarkable for vessel occlu sion (Fig.  1a and b). MRI showed nonspecific, diffuse 
irregular dural/pachymeningeal thickening enhancement 
(Fig.  2a and b). Radiology and oncology reviewed MRI 
imaging and suggested leptomeningeal disease involve ment is likely, although was unable to be confirmed by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cytology due to thrombocyto penia (Fig. 3).
In the 18  months prior to his presentation, his dis ease progressed despite treatment including leuprolide, 
apalutamide, enzalutamide with rucaparib on a clinical 
trial, docetaxel, palliative radiotherapy to the spine and 
femur, and radium-223. Abiraterone was started. Labo ratory work-up was unremarkable and did not explain 
the patient’s speech disturbance, which included diffi culty initiating a sentence, delayed speech with stuttering 
quality, and difficulty with articulation. Upon evaluation 
by neurology, electroencephalogram (EEG) was nega tive for an epileptiform correlate. The workup included a 
lumbar puncture to rule out infectious etiology. Labora tory values of the patient’s prostate-specific antigen were 
increasing despite multiple prior lines of treatment.
The patient’s neurological status stabilized, and he was 
discharged home with a plan for continued therapy with 
abiraterone and prednisone. Due to advanced malig nancy, the patient enrolled in hospice and died 3 weeks 
after hospital discharge. Autopsy was not performed.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusions
Leptomeningeal metastasis occurs in approximately 
5% of patients with prostate cancer and typically indi cates a very poor prognosis [8 ]. The most common 
brain metastases are from organs such as the lungs, 
kidneys, breasts, melanomas, and colorectal neoplasms 
[9, 10]. Despite the high prevalence of prostate can cer, metastasis to the leptomeninges is uncommon and 
is usually seen in patients with other osseous and soft 
tissue metastases. In a study of 16,280 patients with 
prostate carcinoma, only 131 patients had craniospi nal metastasis, which was then further divided into 
Fig. 1 a Computed tomography unremarkable for evidence of acute ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke. b Computed tomography angiogram 
unremarkable for vessel occlusion

intraparenchymal metastasis (103 or 79%), dural metas tasis (28 or 21%), and leptomeningeal disease (5, or 4%) 
[7]. Of these 131 patients, the most common symp tom or finding was headaches (36%), delirium (51%), 
memory deficits (17%), asymptomatic (11%), and cra nial nerve VII or other lower cranial nerve neuropa thies (9%). Other symptoms and findings, which ranged 
from 3% to 7% of cases, included diplopia, hemiparesis, 
visual field cuts, seizures, ataxia, and finally aphasia. 
Aphasia was present in 3 of the 131 patients, account ing for the least common finding in patients with 
craniospinal metastasis from prostate carcinoma [9 ]. 
Evaluations including CSF cytology and histopathology 
are required for confirmation of diagnosis, which was 
limited in our patient due to thrombocytopenia and 
patient’s desire for no autopsy. Using imaging findings and clinical course, our suspicion was that leptomenin geal metastasis was a possible cause.
Our patient underwent extensive therapy that included 
leuprolide, apalutamide, enzalutamide with rucaparib 
on a clinical trial, docetaxel, palliative radiotherapy to 
the spine and femur, and radium-223. These therapeu tic options demonstrate the growing advances in medi cal oncology, which have increased life expectancy. As 
patients live longer, metastatic disease may progress in 
unorthodox locations and patients may display unique 
clinical presentations. A single-institution retrospec tive observational study assessed the incidence of brain 
metastases before and after the docetaxel therapy regi men, finding that metastases to the brain occurred in 
0.8% of patients in the pre-docetaxel time versus 2.8% 
in post-docetaxel therapy availability [10]. With the 
now robust and multiple therapeutic options for pros tate cancer, the incidence of leptomeningeal metastases 
is expected to rise, leading to the importance of further 
studies and evaluations discussing prostate cancer and 
brain metastasis.
Due to the scarcity of leptomeningeal metastases in 
prostate cancer, diagnostic approaches involving brain 
imaging are not always indicated. Even with multiple 
available diagnostic approaches, which include inte grated positron emission tomography (patch), magnetic 
resonance imaging (MRI) scanners, and prostate-specific 
membrane antigen with 18 F labeled and 68 GA labeled 
agents, central nervous system metastases in prostate 
cancer remains a challenging diagnosis [11]. In an 11-year 
analysis of imaging characteristics of leptomeningeal 
metastases from prostate cancer, the MRI appearance

was highly variable and often led to a poor prognosis. Of 
the 21 patients studied, the most common sites of paren chymal brain metastases were the frontal lobes, which 
were involved in 86% of patients. The enhancement pat tern varied from purely solid to mixed cystic and solid to 
ringlike [12]. In these 21 patients, only 7 had pathologi cally proven metastasis. In our patient, the nonspecific 
findings of diffuse irregular dural/pachymeningeal thick ening and enhancement did not provide a clear diagno sis and were not seen in the aforementioned study of the 
frontal lobe as the most involved region. Similar limita tions of inability to obtain histopathology were present to 
confirm diagnosis.
